intro.text: Our research aims to bring **usable, reliable, and verifiable statistical guarantees** to modern machine learning, especially **large models**.

We focus on **distribution-free predictive inference**: under weak assumptions, we build prediction sets and confidence outputs with **finite-sample coverage and risk control**. We also study the theory of **conformal prediction**, including tuning bias and test-time validity.

On the system side, we connect distribution-free inference with large models for **fast inference** and **hybrid labeling**, to get reliable uncertainty and quality control. We also work on **high-dimensional statistics**, **transfer learning**, **survival modeling with structural change**, and **reliable inference** in **spatial statistics**.

areas.title: Distribution-Free Predictive Inference
areas.summary: We design prediction sets with finite-sample guarantees, and study key effects in conformal prediction such as tuning bias and test-time validity.

narrative.text: We study why conformal prediction can drift when tuning and calibration are not separated, and we build theory that explains a clear scaling pattern in tuning bias.
We also design conformal methods that stay valid in harder settings, such as online prediction with label noise and spatially correlated data.
More broadly, we work on test-time valid selection and efficient conformal procedures.

areas.title: Reliable LLM Systems
areas.summary: We connect distribution-free inference with large-model systems for fast reasoning and cost-efficient data work, with clear statistical guarantees on risk and quality.

narrative.text: For fast reasoning, we design switching rules that save compute while controlling performance loss, and we study the limits of conditional guarantees in the distribution-free setting.
For data work, we build LLMâ€“human hybrid pipelines with strict error-rate control, and we design auditing tools (such as FDR control) for labeling and training data identification.

areas.title: High-Dimensional Statistics
areas.summary: We develop robust and efficient methods for high-dimensional and heterogeneous data, including transfer learning, quantile-based tools, and survival models with structural change.

narrative.text: We develop robust tools for heterogeneous and heavy-tailed data, including quantile-based integrative analysis and robust estimation for dependent time series.
We also build data-driven methods for survival models with threshold effects, and we release practical software for these models.
We study how to borrow strength under spatial dependence to improve prediction with limited target data in transfer learning.
We also study selective inference for identified group structures.

areas.title: Spatial Statistics
areas.summary: We work on spatial dependence and heterogeneity, with a focus on reliable inference for real prediction tasks.

narrative.text: We develop methods that combine spatial dependence with modern learning goals, and we focus on reliability and finite-sample guarantees.
A key theme is to handle heterogeneous spatial effects and limited target data in real prediction problems.
